description: The Móstoles City Council launched a solution fully aligned with the Smart City philosophy that allowed it to put all its information on a single platform. In addition to this, it is incorporating sensors in different areas of the city, starting with the streetlights, in order to be able to exhaustively monitor their situation and conservation. On the other hand, from the town hall, citizens will be involved through 'Mejora Móstoles', an app to be a collaborative asset within this great project, providing information to the city council that would allow them to enjoy, at all times, of the best municipal service. In addition, thanks to ArcGIS Online, they were able to develop different storymaps to inform residents of the actions that are carried out, as well as the services they make available to them.

name: Valladolid Street Map
description: The Valladolid City Council has a long history in the use of Geographic Information Systems (GIS). The technicians of its cartographic center have collected for years a large amount of cartographic information, which they update daily, but which to date had not been made openly available to the rest of the departments or their nearly 300,000 citizens, among others. reasons, due to the lack of a single repository. Taking into account the need to create a cross-sectional corporate GIS platform that would serve all its departments, the City Council decided to undertake the project by updating its local street map using ArcGIS. In the first place, the cartographic center carried out a preliminary study of all that information that could be georeferenced. Once analyzed, it was decided to provide the street map with three thematic maps

name: Granada Human Smart City
description: Esri's ArcGIS Platform has enabled Granada to make its rich historical and cultural heritage available to everyone, regardless of their mobility profile. Granada Human Smart City is an example of how GIS technology is capable of making our cities more livable, sustainable and intelligent by making decisions based on geographic data. One of the first initiatives undertaken consisted in the development, by the consulting and engineering company IDOM, of a Spatial Data Infrastructure (IDE) that would serve to unite, through ArcGIS Server, all the geographic information of the city. In this way, the City Council has obtained a complete inventory of the real estate infrastructure of its neighborhoods, specifically, Albaicín and Sacromonte, both UNESCO World Heritage Sites and the main objectives of the “ Granada Human Smart City ” project

name: Xeoportal IDE Sanitago de Compostela
description: The City Council of Santiago de Compostela, in its commitment to improving urban planning and the quality of life of its nearly 95,000 inhabitants, was looking for a way to put its data, referring to an area of ​​nearly 20,000 hectares, at the service of professionals and citizens , in a useful and cohesive way. The City opted for the development of a geoportal that brings together local geographic information, so that it is easy to consult. This initiative materialized with the development  of the Santiago de Compostela Xeoportal IDE , based on ArcGIS. The platform allows the user to consult, both in Galician and in Spanish, geographic information divided into different areas: a generic web viewer, several prominent thematic viewers, an information download section and a section especially oriented to urban management, among others.

name: GIS for Fire Management in the Doñana National Park
description:
In 2017, the Doñana National Park suffered the most aggressive fire in its history, affecting almost 10,000 hectares and endangering numerous protected natural surroundings inhabited by numerous protected animal species, such as the Iberian lynx. Once the fire was declared, the main challenge of INFOCA, the Device for the Prevention and Extinction of Forest Fires of the Andalusian Government, was to manage all the data related to the fire in real time and without precision error. The solution was to display a map in ArcGIS Online with which the different operations involved in fire management could make a real analysis and monitoring of the fire.
In this collaborative map, all the elements related to the fire were positioned, both at the level of extinction areas, propagation, etc., as well as all the deployed devices: firefighters, police, medical personnel, etc.

name: The use of GIS for the control and response to the Tiger Mosquito
description:
Pests are a public health problem, especially in large cities. For this reason, the town councils have specific teams for their prevention and management, this is the case of the Madrid City Council, which has the Madrid Salud service to attack and prevent any plague of any species: rats, cockroaches, ticks or new species. not indigenous. The work of Madrid Salud focuses on making an inventory of the areas of Madrid that may favor the nesting of the tiger mosquito.
In this sense, Geographic Information Systems are of vital importance for locating areas prone to harboring microfoci of reproduction, as well as for managing human resources, entomological surveillance fleets and spatial information.
In this way, the maps prepared by Madrid Salud collect information of all kinds, from small fountains and sources of humidity, such as terraces with toys that tend to accumulate water, to breeding sources associated with tires, such as gas stations, rest areas, airports , workshops or scrap yards, passing through sewage systems, patios, urban gardens, bollards, etc.

name: Monitoring of Solid Waste Hauling and Street Sweeping Vehicles: Smart City Valencia
description: The aim of this project is to provide a single corporate computing platform that allows the integration of all the different systems in which information is currently being introduced by the areas that carry out field activities. This platform will ensure the creation, development and implementation of a horizontal information tool that guarantees an adequate coordination of field operations in relation to the different activities of the city: maintenance, management and inspection, thus integrating on the VLCi Platform all the information that is extracted from the vehicles.

name: Smart Heritage Management: Smart City Valencia
description: This action is specific to the protection of a space as unique as the La Almoina Archaeological Center in València. The protection of this environment includes the deployment of a meteorological station that together with the temperature and humidity sensors that will help to maintain the right environmental conditions in the museum and guarantee the correct preservation of the archaeological remains. Security will also be improved by means of presence sensors and video surveillance. The obtained data is transmitted to the VLCi platform for monitoring of the environmental conditions of the Museum, enhancing real time alarms for a quicker security response. The data can be visualized through dashboards or at the GIS Portal of the City Council. In addition, internal KPIs can be generated to know the evolution of the key parameters of the installation.

name: Smart Parking: Smart City Valencia
description: This initiative is expected to be just the first step towards the total sensorization of these spaces in the city. It will provide real-time information on the status of parking spaces for limited mobility collectives (425 seats), loading and unloading areas (125 seats) and taxi rank areas (126 seats).

name: Geoportal Smart City Valencia
description: The objective of this action is to replace the existing GIS architecture with a service-oriented architecture that allows providing new functionalities to the Municipal Geographic Information System, as well as the migration of the applications used in the current environment to the new architecture. This action aims to incorporate the geographical component as one more aspect of the Smart City, so that the city can be managed not only based on alphanumeric information, but also on the location where information has been produced related with the available assets of the City Council deployed throughout Valencia. This will allow for a holistic vision of the city combining data, location, trends and indicators.

name: Environmental Sensors on Buses: Smart City Valencia
description: Installation of 40 devices onboard buses of different lines of the Council Transportation Company of València is to carry out measurements of air quality, as well as monitor the temperature and humidity in the city. It will allow to have more information in the VLCi platform for the calculation of the air quality index (AQI) of the city of Valencia. Currently this calculation is barely based on the data obtained in real time from the only 6 air quality measurement stations installed in the city of Valencia (competency of the Generalitat Valenciana).

name: Management of Urban Noise: Smart City Valencia
description: Sound level meters will be deployed in the most frequented leisure areas of València to have measurements of the noise level available, as well as being able to make real time decisions the moment noise levels increase significantly or are detected in a sustained manner over time. These zones will be Benimaclet, Pl. Honduras, Av. Aragón, Pl. Cedro, Cruz Cubierta, Paseo de la Alameda, Pl. Cánovas, C/ Juan Llorens and Russafa District. Thanks to this project, it will be possible to characterize daily noise patterns (day / evening / night), weekly (days of greater acoustic conflictivity, weekends, etc.) as well as seasonal ones.

name: Smart Lighting: Smart City Valencia
description: With this action intelligence will be provided to 65 control groups and 2,000 luminaries in the northern and southern Towns of the city. Thanks to these devices it will be possible to have real-time information on the status of the different lighting sections that exist in these areas and improve environmental sustainability by drastically reducing consumption. These areas of the city have been selected due to their vulnerability to copper theft and with these devices these situations can be detected in real time.

name: Operational Mobility Center: Smart City Amsterdam
description: This Operational Mobility Center (OMC) aims to keep Amsterdam Southeast accessible, liveable and accessible around events in the area. Together with the stakeholders involved in mobility and the organization of events, the traffic flows in and to the area are prepared, monitored and managed in the right direction. The shared data and video images provide a holistic picture of the situation. By comparing real-time data with historical data, assumptions can be made about the further course of the situation. This makes it possible to anticipate and prevent potential problems. In addition, a so-called Common Operational Picture has been realized. In this dashboard, the pressures for the various mobility flows are displayed in real time. In this way, all the different parties involved have an overview of the current status at a glance. In this way, the operational staff, from transport providers to road authorities and the police, can act immediately to remedy and even prevent the bottlenecks.

name: Parksharing: Smart City Amsterdam
description: The platform shows which companies and organizations are in the municipality and what they can do for each other. Companies can then offer and purchase their products and services among themselves. In addition, companies can match and share the supply and demand of company resources, materials, residual flows, services, personnel and facilities.

name: Urban Nature Amsterdam
description: In May 2018 we started a crowdfunding campaign to develop a special instrument with lets you see which green and blue spots can be found in the immediate vicinity of your home or workspace. Our three partners are the Municipality of Amsterdam, Waterschap Amstel, Gooi en Vecht and Recreatie Noord-Holland. Staatsbosbeheer supported the development of a special instrument with lets you see which green and blue spots can be found in the immediate vicinity of your home or workspace. The paper-based map offers a unique sensory experience which cannot be reproduced digitally. This big map – covering more than one square meter of information on both sides of the paper needs to be discovered to really learn to appreciate it. It is a cartographic gem that shows urban nature in the city and its surroundings. Urban Good (design) and Nature Desks (research & projectmanagement) have worked for almost a year on the production; the aim was to get people to observe and experience 'their' city in a different way.

name: EyeBeacons: Wayfinding in Amsterdam's Public Spaces
description: The EyeBeacons project (Amsterdam University of Applied Sciences, Visio, Bartiméus, HAN and Info.nl) investigated how new technologies can support people with a visual impairment when navigating through the city. Important results are a demo smartphone and smartwatch app, which helps prepare the trip, can provide extensive navigation instructions and can provide information about the area. The aim is to scale-up this project by enhancing the exposure and applications of the EyeBeacons smartphone and smartwatch app in Amsterdam but also in other municipalities in the Netherlands and abroad. Other cities must be aware that the results and implementation of EyeBeacons are necessary for the mobility of Visually Impaired People.

name: OpenStreetMap in Malaga
description: OpenStreetMap is a collaborative project to create a free editable geographic database of the world. The geodata underlying the maps is considered the primary output of the project. The creation and growth of OSM has been motivated by restrictions on use or availability of map data across much of the world, and the advent of inexpensive portable satellite navigation devices. Also for Malaga an OpenStreetMap is being developed. OpenStreetMap is open data, licensed under the Open Data Commons Open Database License (ODbL) by the OpenStreetMap Foundation (OSMF).

name: EasyWay Krakow: Public Transport Map
description: EasyWay provides a current map of bus routes in Krakow. It allows to search for routes from A to B via the use of the Krakow road map. An application is available for Android and Apple devices.

name: Open Street Map Transit Routes in Rennes
description: OpenStreetMap is a collaborative project to create a free editable geographic database of the world. The geodata underlying the maps is considered the primary output of the project. The creation and growth of OSM has been motivated by restrictions on use or availability of map data across much of the world, and the advent of inexpensive portable satellite navigation devices. Also for Rennes an OpenStreetMap is being developed. OpenStreetMap is open data, licensed under the Open Data Commons Open Database License (ODbL) by the OpenStreetMap Foundation (OSMF).

name: Citizen Location Services for Police: Scotland
description: People who get lost in a remote or rural area can now use a mobile phone app to identify their location when calling Police Scotland on 999 or 101. The what3words app divides the world into 3x3 metre squares using GPS coordinates and gives each square a unique set of three words. Users can then communicate their location by giving the three words even if they do not know where they are, are in an unfamiliar area, rural location or one that is difficult to describe. The app, which is free of charge to members of the public, emergency services and charities, is already being used by the majority of emergency services across the UK, including the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service and Scottish Ambulance Service. Police also plan to use the app to support local incidents and pre-planned operations and events.

name: Local tourism insights from MPD Setomaa in South Estonia
description: In Estonia, the national Government uses mobile positioning data to monitor the flow of tourists in the country, including their start and end destination, nationality and their length of trip. This data is captured by the Estonian Tourist Board in a Tourism Dashboard and is used to support strategic planning. The Board also gives access to the dashboard to local and regional tourism organisations to support their planning and operations. In the region of Setomaa, the local tourism organisation has used the dashboard to better understand tourist flows, target marketing and measure the impact of their policies.  It is expected that this location intelligence will also drive political value through the promotion of economic development.

name: GIS Platform and AI for Roads and Highways in Bavaria
description: The state of Bavaria takes pride in its strategic location as the centre of Europe and has prioritized investing resources to ensure the health of its highway systems. With evolving needs in the transportation sector the challenge that the administration is facing is utilizing digitized assets efficiently and investing in strategic conservation methods for the road network infrastructure. Therefore the Bavarian State Ministry of Housing, Building and Transport created, with a team of data scientists at Supper & Supper, an AI proof-of-concept model that predicts wear and tear on a highly trafficked highway connecting multiple cities and towns in southern Germany, so that road maintenance can be efficiently planned at the proper time and location based on highway conditions. A technology stack of ArcGIS Pro and open source Python frameworks was utilized to access, wrangle, impute, analyze, and visualize data and results. The final results were then published and visualized in ArcGIS Pro, with each road section symbolized to illustrate where road unevenness and cracks would likely develop over time.

name: City Pulse: Stratumseind Living Lab
description: The CityPulse pilot scheme was developed by Atos and a number of partners including Intel, The City of Eindhoven and The Dutch Institute of Safety and Security (DITSS). Its aim is to help the City of Eindhoven manage a street in the centre of town – Stratumseind – the longest and most vibrant street in the Netherlands with more than 50 bars and nightclubs and where 15-20,000 people visit every weekend. Fewer and fewer people wanted to come to the pub street as a consequence of all too many stories about aggressiveness on the street. The municipality decided to intervene via a living lab for crowd control, looking over large groups of people. The street is now full of high-tech material for collecting data. The project is now entering its final phase and the time of data collection and writing algorithms slowly passes into the period of actual use.

name: MPD to track tourist mobility in Chemin d'Arles
description: Mobile Positioning Data is used to monitor cross-border mobility patterns; a pilot project based on Chemin d'Arles – a medieval pilgrim route running between France and Spain – is using Mobile Positioning Data to analyse tourism flows between the two countries.

name: How Busy is Toon: City Occupancy in Glasgow
description: How Busy Is Toon is here to help you feel safe and prepared when visiting your city centre. You have access to still images updated usually every five minutes from around the city centre, access to still images usually updated every 15 minutes of traffic cams of popular roads in and out of the city centre, live data on car park capacity, real time bus data, and up to date rules and safety guidance from councils and government. The platform was initially built in 2020 in collaboration with Newcastle City Council, NE1, Newcastle University’s Research Software Engineering team, and hedgehog lab, using data from the Urban Observatory, and data analytics from National Innovation Centre for Data. Since then we have updated and improved the site based on user feedback.

name: Fix My Street in Zurich City Council
description: In March 2013, the City of Zurich launched the reporting system for public infrastructure «Züri wie neu» as a pilot project. The application has been introduced to regular operations after one year. The platform, which is available both as mobile app and website, is well received within the population and has become indispensable for the city's administration. Over 15,000 incidents have already been reported (as of November 2018). «Züri wie neu» is based on the British geo-data-based application «Fix my street». Since the implementation in Zurich, other municipalities, such as Winterthur and St. Gallen, have established similar reporting systems for their residents.

name: Geocode System to Crowdsource Information on Fly-tipping
description: Having seen how successful the What3Words app has been across the world, East Northamptonshire Council (ENC) is now encouraging anyone who wishes to report fly tipping across the district to use the app. What3Words works using the principle that every 3m x 3m square of the world has been assigned an address of three words. For example one 3m x 3m square at East Northamptonshire Council’s Cedar Drive office can be identified more precisely as ‘Corded.Clean.Eased’ as opposed to ENC’s postcode of NN14 4LZ which covers a larger area. Via the app fly tipping can be reported more precisely, allowing it to be located more quickly and dealt with by Council officers, especially in more rural areas of the district where a postcode typically cover a much wider area.

name: Tvarkau Vilniu Platform: Non-emergency Citizen Reporting App
description: The Tvarkau Vilnių platform was originally launched in 2012 in order to streamline the process of gathering information from the public regarding issues in the city. Following the development of Tvarkau Vilnių mobile applications for iOS and Android, between 2014 and 2015 the number of reports doubled, then nearly doubled again between 2015 and 2016. Take-up increased even further in 2017, when an option to submit reports anonymously was added. Anonymous reporting is one of the features that differentiates Tvarkau Vilnių from the more widely known FixMyStreet platform. The municipality itself is in primary charge of the platform.

name: Tickin App; Journey Planning in Rhein Neckar
description: Simple, flexible and fair - Deutsche Bahn's new ticket app Tickin has been making travelling by bus and train in the Rhine-Neckar Transport Network (VRN) easier since 1 July 2020. No more buying tickets at ticket machines, no more searching for the right tariff zone and the cheapest ticket - simply check in via Tickin and start travelling. Checking out at the destination is done automatically by Tickin. For this, the customer pays the VRN eTariff, which is calculated from the linear distance between the starting point and the destination. In addition to the simple and convenient ticket purchase, there is another major advantage: tickets are checked contactless on the trains as well as on the buses and trams. Billing takes initially place via PayPal, with other payment methods to follow shortly.

name: Rail Network Monitoring in Kent
description: SatSense produces maps of ground deformation that are updated on a regular basis. These maps show movement of the ground with mm/year accuracy, which can be used to identify potential hazards for rail networks such as landslides. SatSense takes readings from radar satellite and converts it to high resolution ground movement. The Sentinel-1 constellation consists of two radarbearing satellites, which between them return to the same orbit every six days and acquire a new radar image. Sophisticated processing of these images using proprietary SatSense algorithms, which build on a technique known as InSAR, produces detailed maps of ground movement between satellite passes. These maps show movement either towards or away from the satellite and by combining images acquired from different geometries, horizontal and vertical motion can be derived. SatSense algorithms build on academic algorithms developed by founders Andy Hooper and Tim Wright, Professors at the University of Leeds, and in particular on new algorithms that allow us to robustly separate signal from noise at high spatial resolution data (InSAR).

name: Digital Twin for Mobility Monitoring
description: The Yorkshire Geospatial Twin partnership will make Yorkshire and Humber a global pioneer in the field of smart cities. The project focuses on the use of ‘digital twin’ technology to improve the transport network in Leeds, York and Hull and will be one of the largest of its type in the world. The platform will auto-generate 3D models of the three cities and surrounding areas, allowing planners to test different ways to boost the capacity of the existing network, reduce congestion and air pollution. Also ways to investigate the improvement of logistics and to deal with potential delays at the port of Hull will be studied. The Yorkshire Geospatial Twin partnership brings together Slingshot with the three city councils along with Arup and BT Group, and will funded by Innovate UK and the Geospatial Commission.

name: Sensors4Rail Pilot Project: Digital Twin of Railway in Hamburg
description: Sensors4Rail Pilot Project focuses on the development of a digital railway twin in Hamburg. In the pilot, Deutsche Bahn will equip a Hamburg S-Bahn train with innovative sensors that locate the train and monitor surroundings, which can be localised on the HD map, which effectively creates a digital twin of the railway. An important component for the Sensors4Rail pilot project is an HD map, a digital map of high-definition quality. It enables the train to pinpoint itself precisely on the tracks, and recognise and classify obstacles by sensing and surveying its surroundings. These can be accurately localised on the HD map so that in the future, the train control centre can react even faster. Ultimately, this technology set-up will enable Deutsche Bahn to increase the capacity by keeping more trains running on the tracks simultaneously. In effect, the map becomes the digital twin of the railway and its immediate surroundings. Through its location platform, HERE provides Deutsche Bahn with a private development environment to independently manage its data. The data remain fully under the ownership and control of Deutsche Bahn.

name: Environmental Monitoring in Jotunheimen National Park
description: Tourism has boomed in national parks in Norway in recent years, such as in Jotunheimen National Park for which this study applies. We test the use of drones on a site where new tourist facilities will be established to set a baseline to identify future changes. We demonstrate how drones could help protected area management by monitoring visitor use pat-terns and commonly associated impacts such as trail condition (width and depth), vegetation structure and disturbances, informal trail proliferation, tram-pling, and trash and other impacts along the trails. The accuracy and reliability was assessed, compared with intensive ﬁeld measurements of impacts and found low-cost drones to be effective in mapping the study area with a resolution of 0.5 cm/pixel: drone derived trail measurements were comparable to traditional measurements with a negligible divergence on trail width measurements and a consistent1.05 cm divergence on trail depth measurements that can be corrected with a few validation points. In addition, a high-resolution vegetation classiﬁcation map that could be used as a baseline for monitoring impacts was created. It was concluded that drones can effectively contribute to visitor monitoring by reducing time spent in the ﬁeld and by providing high-resolution time series that could be used as baseline to measure tourism impacts on conservation values in protected areas.

name: Capacity Management Solution for the Beaches of the Costa del Sol
description: The Costa del Sol received more than 13 million visitors in 2019. Its main attraction, the beaches and the tourism offer linked to them. For this reason, Tourism and Planning of the Costa del Sol, a body dependent on the Provincial Council of Malaga, faced one of its greatest challenges in 2020: managing the capacity of its beaches. Two solutions were developed. Firstly, a total capacity control solution to control the total capacity of each of the beaches, taking into account various indicators related to the location, the bathers and the surroundings of the beaches. Based on this, a map of the real space of the bathers was obtained. From there, they only had to calculate the capacity according to the regulations of each municipality, which could have as a reference the 2 metres of interpersonal distance recommended by the Central Government, but which in some municipalities was increased to 12 metres to take into account the characteristics of the bathers who used to go to these beaches. Secondly, there is the monitoring: A pilot project was launched with two town councils aimed at monitoring the situation of each beach in real time and through a control panel. One of these municipalities was Mijas, one of the most touristic municipalities on the Costa del Sol.

name: Locating Mobile Blood-testing Units in Lothian
description: National Health Service (NHS) Lothian delivers care for patients who’ve had kidney transplants or have chronic kidney disease. At the start of Britain’s COVID-19 measures, Ordnance Survey (OS) used its Points of Interest and OS Highways data to help identify safe and accessible locations for a mobile team to take blood samples. This meant they could monitor patients’ health safely and easily, away from the busy hospital. Supermarkets with car parks were a clear choice. OS mixed different datasets to show all supermarket locations and their footprints along with nearby car parks. Then the NHS Lothian GIS team narrowed the selection based on size, location, and likelihood of getting agreement from the supermarket. The team prioritised spaces that had already been used for other mobile health services – such as breast cancer screening. NHS Lothian combined the locations with anonymised patient addresses – converted to coordinates and displayed using MapInfo software and a range of OS products (Points of Interest, OS Highways, and Open Map Local). From this, we could identify the best places to support these vulnerable patients. OS gave its information under our well-established Mapping for Emergencies protocol – here to support Britain in times of crisis.

name: Reducing Obesity through mapping Fast Food Vendors in Birmingham
description: Obesity is a huge problem in Birmingham, costing the city’s NHS (National Health Service) £330 million a year. Almost a quarter of Year Six children are officially obese, with statistics directly linking takeaways close to schools to high levels of obesity. By using Ordnance Survey’s OS Street View, Birmingham’s Public Health team could produce a map showing the high number of takeaways near schools across the city. As well as providing valuable information, the map is easy to share and has given headteachers and planning departments the data to support opposition to applications for new fast food outlets near schools. Following the development of this easy to use map: (1) The spread of unhealthy fast food outlets around schools has significantly slowed, (2) the local planning department has adopted a policy to limit the number of new fast food outlets, and (3) since the policy, almost half of applications for new takeaways have been denied. No more than 10 percent of units in any shopping area can now be takeaways.

name: Hospital Location Planning in Somerset
description: In 2014, Somerset Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG) looked into how a proposed centralised stroke service, based at Taunton Hospital, would affect the population of Somerset as a whole. Public Sector Mapping Agreement (PSMA) data from Ordnance Survey provided critical evidence leading to Somerset CCG keeping stroke services at both Yeovil and Taunton hospitals. The South West Commissioning Support (SWCS) Unit’s Geographical Information System (GIS) team used innovative analytical techniques with MapInfo Professional, RouteFinder and Basemap’s TRACC system – designed to quickly and accurately calculate various travel times. Maps and reports were produced showing travel access times to the two current hospital sites at Taunton and Yeovil. These included blue light emergency transport times, private and public transport options, population numbers within travel times, and locations of stroke cases.

name: Belfast Civic Dollar App
description: The Belfast City Council is piloting a mobile phone app that rewards users for spending time in a local park. The free Civic Dollars app will track users’ locations and reward them for each half hour spent in Connswater Community Greenway, a linear park following the course of three rivers through east Belfast, with a daily limit. The city plans to add other parks during the pilot, which runs from 1 June to 31 August. The resulting ‘dollars’ can be spent on transport passes and tickets to visitor attractions. They can also be donated to community groups in the city, which can use them for services including business training and professional advice. The app has been developed by Ballymena-based Moai Digital. The Civic Dollars app also provides a promotional platform for local businesses, services and events – and the insights we’ll gather will help us to better understand how people use green spaces, improve park management, reduce vandalism, littering and anti-social behaviour and enhance the visitor experience. The pilot is part of Belfast City Council’s ‘Amazing spaces, smart places’ programme, for which it ran a funding competition with the Northern Ireland Department of Justice in 2018.

name: Hindrance Premium tool in Flanders
description: The Hindrance Premium tool allows small enterprises affected by serious hindrance from roadworks to receive a financial subsidy. If there is hindrance from roadworks in the neighborhood of your premises, there is no need to take action. The affected small enterprise will receive a letter from the public administration if it is qualified for a hindrance premium. The premium allows them to inform their customers and to continue serving them during this period. There is a maximum amount of 2000 EUR.

name: Underground Asset Register in Northumbria and London
description: In April 2019 the Geospatial Commission announced a twelve month ‘National Underground Assets Register’ pilot.The aim was to increase the government’s understanding of how such a register could be designed and managed.The overall cost was £2.4 million.Each pilot provided insight and evidence to inform an approach for how a national programme could be rolled out. The pilots were aimed to design and test what a mapping platform could look like to help asset owners, such as telecommunication, energy and water companies and local authorities securely share their existing underground asset data with authorised users. Early research identified two suitable areas for launching pilots: (1) in the north east of England, the North East Underground Infrastructure Hub (NEUIHub) was created following Northumbrian Water Group’s 2018 Innovation Festival, and (2) in London, the Highways Apparatus Data Exchange System (HADES), an early proof of concept, was initiated in 2017.

name: Flanders Digital Underground Utility Location System
description: Development of an underground asset registry - core feature is the data exchange between different utility providers. The data sharing arrangements agreed were included within legislation. Much more efficient system for map requests - the delivery time dropped 50% saving time and money. The KLIP platform has the responsibility to package and present these answers into the map viewer, with one base map, presented in accordance to the presentation model PMKL. This viewer is available as an online and standalone offline PC version. As of 2018, tablet versions for Android and iOS will be available. The map request initiator will use the KLIP viewer when preparing or executing the excavations, they can print the maps or download the vector data tin order to integrate into a CAD system for combining with other data. Integration of APIs to enable faster map requests.

name: Spotbooking in Flanders
description: Spotbooking is a smart city solution that raises the public service of a public administration towards citizens to a higher level. Spotbooking consists of various modules, including taking public domain, events and terraces. Advising on, processing and enforcing requests becomes a simple process that is completely digital. Various public administrations in Belgium are using the tool, including the city of Leuven, who consider Spotbooking to have “a strong, user-friendly front office, which makes the counter function virtually superfluous. 99% of all requests are made, processed, paid for and delivered online. This saves a lot of time for the applicant, but also for the front desk staff.”.

name: MijnTuinLab (MyGardenLab) : Citizen Science Platform
description: 9% of Flanders consists of gardens. An enormous potential for nature and science. But what grows in those 9%? Nobody has a clue about this blind spot in Flanders. Except those living there. With My Garden Lab the owners/users get an insight into what their garden can do for them and how it can help science. Add up all the small patches of private greenery and you can see immediately that this area of gardens can mean a lot to nature and science in Flanders. Besides being a place for relaxation, gardening, sport and play, gardens also provide many benefits. Services such as water storage, habitat for animals and plants and even a buffer against climate change. We call these 'ecosystem services' or nature benefits. My GardenLab wants to map out these nature benefits and make sure that the owner/user can enjoy a healthy garden at the same time. Because a healthy garden is a garden that also looks after the owner/user.

name: AirBezen: Air Quality Map in Antwerp
description: Citizens Science, involving them in monitoring air quality (see INSPIRE Conference Antwerp). The AIRbezen project is a clever word pun on the Flemish of Antwerp dialect word for strawberries (jarrebezen) and, obviously, the word air. By examining the leaves of strawberry plants, AIRbezen maps the air quality of a city or province. Strawberry plants are distributed among families, schools or associations, who give the plant a place on the windowsill. After 2 months the strawberry-hosts cut off a few leaves and bring them in at the distribution points. The researchers at the University of Antwerp then measure the concentrations of particulate matter on the leaves, thus revealing to what the plant was exposed.

name: Heidelberg smart waste
description: The city of Heidelberg relies on the Internet of Things for waste management. With the IoT platform SAP Leonardo IoT, Heidelberg can better plan the routes of waste collection vehicles. Together with SAP Digital Business Services, the Digital Agentur Heidelberg and other partners, the city of Heidelberg installed ultrasonic sensors in the containers. The sensors record the fill level of the containers in real time and transmit this information hourly to the backend in the SAP Cloud Platform via the long-range radio technology LoRaWAN (Long Range Wide Area Network). In this way the waste disposal company knows exactly when which container needs to be emptied. In addition, the collected data can be further processed. Using the SAP Waste and Recycling Management System, managers can create further analyses to predict waste quantities at peak times and adjust the effort required for disposal accordingly. In the future, the city wants to digitally network other infrastructures together with SAP. The potential for smartification of district heating shafts, electricity and water meters, grit silos or in building management, for example, is great.

name: Amsterdam Beacon Mile
description: The Amsterdam Beacon Mile is a route of 2 km that has beacons lining it. This is seen as a testing area for applications such as public wayfinding, tourist routes, iBeacon signing, Hyperlocal points of interest and augmenting existing apps with additional proximity data. Citizens can find the city’s Beacon Mile between Amsterdam Central Station and the Marineterrein. When a citizen walks on the Beacon Mile and has the app installed on its smartphone the beacon will emit signals. The emitted signals will then be decoded by the smartphone. The beacons are located in different places along the Beacon Mile. Furthermore, the signal will then be transformed into the pre-programmed message. The message sent to the user will appear as a pop up on the smartphone. It can contain important information, discounts or to help to discover the route. Most importantly, the city of Amsterdam has been showing a lot of progress in their journey to become a smart city. The city’s local government stimulates different innovative projects. This has contributed to a sense of community and a common goal.

name: GIS platform to Manage COVID-19 Mask Supply
description: The supply of protective masks for COVID-19 is a major issue to be dealt with. From the reporting of needs to the management of mask stocks to the organisation of their distribution over the territory, the French agglomeration of Caux Seine Agglo uses the ArcGIS platform. Thanks to this, the decision-makers have a complete and real time vision of the needs and capacity to be provided.

name: Mapping of Species in Cergy-Pontoise
description: The Cergy-Pontoise Biodiversity Atlas is a tool developed by the Cergy-Pontoise Agglomeration Community. It is intended for all stakeholders in the area: residents, associations, local authorities, schoolchildren or passers-by; everyone is invited to share their biodiversity observation data through this platform. All can thus participate in enriching the knowledge of the territory's fauna and flora by taking part in targeted surveys or by transmitting daily data.

name: Loiret Interactive Tourism Map
description: The map, drawn up by the Loiret Department and Tourisme Loiret, lists all the tourist sites in our department. It is regularly updated according to the reopenings to the public. Various layers can be added to the map, providing an indication of the touristic sites, the possible walks to be made in the area and the degree of difficulty.

name: Regio 2N Regional Train Pilot in the North of France
description: SNCF and several partners are fine-tuning the operating system of an ATO train prototype, after which a two-year trial phase will start. The Regio 2N train with GoA2 will operate on the railway net in Northern France. The French national operator works with Alstom, Bosch, Spirops, Thales and the Railenium Technology Research Institute in the project. For two years, the train will be tested on the track between Aulnoye and Busigny, during the school holidays. Outside the research and test periods, the train will be in regular commercial service, transporting passengers. During these regular trips in conventional driving mode, the train will record data that will improve the performance of the signal recognition algorithms. For example,  by detecting the colour of the traffic lights and the surrounding environment of the train. At the same time, laboratory work is being carried out on trial simulators at the sites of all the consortium partners to fine-tune the itineraries of the test train and further develop the automated system. Cybersecurity issues have been taken into consideration from the start of the project. The project partners are working closely with ANSSI (Agence Nationale de la Sécurité des Systèmes d’Information), the French national cybersecurity authority.

name: Real-time Crowding Heatmap
description: The City of Helsinki’s new Heatmap site shows how busy areas and venues are in real-time to help people plan trips while avoiding crowded areas. The project aims to improve safety, support the tourism industry and deliver new data for the city. A colour-coded map, which is updated  every minute, has been developed with software company Hypercell, and the city is installing sensors in the centre and other popular tourist areas to detect anonymous Bluetooth signals from devices such as mobile phones. The signals measure crowd volume, the average time people spend in specific locations, and the movement of crowds within the sensor network.

name: Tracking the Parks of Paris
description: The Internet of Things can help builders and planners gain better insight into the millions of people who move through cities like Paris every day. At Nodle, we’re collaborating data with the City of Paris to put thousands of Bluetooth Low Energy beacons in newly installed urban furniture. These beacons gather data in two separate but complementary manners. First, there’s passive data gathering. The Bluetooth beacons, which will run years or decades without a charge, record when individuals with Bluetooth-enabled phones rest on a bench. Second, Parisians and visitors can participate in active data collection.

name: Shade and Coolness Map in Berlin
description: Climate change is causing ever hotter, drier weather in many places. Berlin, too, has experienced more hot days than ever before in recent years. You can see where, when and how you can find refreshment on such days in this map. It shows you for every hour from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m., where it tends to be rather cool, where there is usually a fresh breeze and where there is currently shade. Due to the differentiated topography, there can be considerable differences within the urban area. You can also discover refreshing places such as swimming areas, drinking fountains and parks. With one click on the share function you can share your new favorite place with others.

name: IssueDoc: Non emergency Citizen reporting
description: Imagine a heavy storm hits a city. Houses are damaged, trees have fallen down, cars are damaged, etc. How can a city or government institution quickly track and manage all those issues? With Issuedoc. Issuedoc brings you an easy, point-and-click mobile solution to report issues and problems and to track issues on a map. With Issuedoc citizens or government representatives can quickly go out and track issues. It even allows you to enhance issues with text and pictures and it can be easily customized to meet the specific needs of cities and local governments.

name: Smart Parking: Park Track
description: Your city is crowded by cars. Shopkeepers are complaining that customers can’t park nearby. Residents can’t park near their houses. Your city needs an effective way to manage a balanced flow of cars, allowing visitors to easily find temporary parking spots, and residents to feel assured they can park their cars near their houses. PARKTRACK is a vital reporting tool to help you enforce parking regulations in your city.

name: W3W in Emergency Services: the case of Ahrweiler
description:
When callers struggle to describe their location, what3words helps them say exactly where they are, saving precious time. They can find their what3words address on the free app or through a FindMe link in an SMS sent by the operator. what3words addresses can be shared easily over text, radio or digitally. This minimises the room for error when incident locations are passed between teams on the ground and different agencies. 
 Responders can then use the what3words app on their mobile devices to find the exact location. In Ahrweiler, Germany, the system was adopted during the emergency response to the floods that caused dramatic human and infrastructure losses. It helped both in rescuing activities and during the following prolonged clearing out.

name: Comuni Chiamo in Ravenna
description:
In 2011 Comuni Chiamo was born to help public administrations to get closer to citizens. It is a platform that simplifies communication with citizens, collaborators, and the public. Comuni Chiamo started to operate in Ravenna in 2018: citizens are now able to direclty communicate with the municipality through Comuni Chiamo app, pointing a light to any problem they see in the municipal territory. Ravenna sought to:
 - Embrace digital channels and consolidate reports from other traditional channel in a unique stream
 -Simplify the resolution process, automate repetitive tasks and create shared knowledge
- Improve collaborations among internal and external stakeholders
-Increase transparency and citizens' collaboration

name: Helpbidea (TRACASA)
description:
Helpbidea aims to answer the request of solving emergency problems trying to reach isolated houses by emergency services. It answers the following questions:
• Where: Those houses do not always have an address per se, and sometimes it is not easy to locate an address (different spellings, unofficial names, etc.)
• How to reach the houses and
• What kind of vehicle could be used to access the houses

name: CurieuzenAir
description: CurieuzenAir is a citizen science initiative in the Brussels Capital Region in which citizens collect data on air quality under the guidance of scientific experts. Through simultaneous measurements at 3000 different locations, air quality in Brussels is mapped and analyzed at unprecedented spatial detail. CurieuzenAir is the largest collaboration ever carried out between scientists and citizens in the Brussels Capital. It is inspired by and builds further on two previous CurieuzeNeuzen projects organized in the City of Antwerp (“CurieuzeNeuzen Antwerp”) and the Flemish Region (“CurieuzeNeuzen Vlaanderen”). These projects examine the air quality of citizens in their streets, by collecting nitrogen dioxide concentrations on a large scale and making available these air quality to the general public. Volunteering citizens and organizations attached a simple measuring device to the outside of a window on the street side, through which they measured the concentration of NO2 throughout an entire month.
